data.name: "Shenzhen I/O" MC4000 Emulator  - basic
data.description: ![shenzen logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/Shenzhen_IO_logo.png) ## MC4000CW Emulator - basic №1 *It would be nice if, before training this kata, you would play SHENZHEN I/O* --- # Storyline You are a Chinese developer who needs to develop an emulator for debugging of microchips "MC X000BB series". Now you have been tasked to write an emulator for the "MC4000CW" chip. --- # "MC4000CW" characteristics 1. Сannot receive more than 9 commands 2. This chip have 1 output --- # I/O Definitions 1. In the input, you get a string in which the commands are divided by ";" * ```python input <= "mov 100 p0;slp 1;mov 0 p0;slp 1;mov 100 p0;slp 3;mov 0 p0;slp 2" #that means: mov 100 p0 slp 1 mov 0 p0 slp 1 mov 100 p0 slp 3 mov 0 p0 slp 2 ``` 1. Signal is integer, may be from 0 to 100 * ```python mov 100 p0 #copy "signal" which has a power of 100 to port0 slp 2 #sleeps 2 ticks mov 50 p0 #copy "signal" which has a power of 50 to port0 slp 2 #sleeps 2 ticks output => [100,100,50,50] ``` 1. In the output, you should send a "list" with "signals" * ```python output => [signal1,signal2,signal3,signal4,signal5,signal6,] #Check slp Explanation for more information about output "list" ``` --- # Documentation Operand types: * R - Register (variable) * I - Integer (int) * R/I - Register or Integer Registers: * acc - Register (Initial value is 0) * p0 - Register (Initial value is 0) Basic comands: * "mov R/I R" - Copy the value of the first operand into the second operand. * "add R/I" - Add the value of the first operand to the value of the acc register and store the result in the acc register * "sub R/I" - Subtract the value of the first operand from the value of the acc register and store the result in the acc register. * "slp R/I" - Sleep for the number of time units specified by the operand. slp Explanation: On `slp` command the emulator goes into the sleep mode for some number of ticks specified in the its argument. On every such tick the value that is currently stored in the `p0` register is written to the output. For example: ```python input = "mov 7 p0;slp 3;mov 20 p0;slp 4" output = [7, 7, 7, 20, 20, 20, 20] ``` --- # Examples ```python input: "mov 0 p0;slp 4;mov 100 p0;slp 2;mov 0 p0;slp 1;mov 100 p0;slp 1" output: [0,0,0,0,100,100,0,100] ``` ```python input: "mov 100 p0;slp 1;mov 0 p0;slp 1;mov 100 p0;slp 3;mov 0 p0;slp 2" output: [100,0,100,100,100,0,0] ``` ```python input: "add 20;mov acc p0;slp 1;add 40;mov acc p0;slp 1;sub 50;mov acc p0;slp 1" output: [20,60,10] ``` ```python input: "mov 50 p0;slp 5;add 25;sub 12;mov acc p0;slp 15" output: [50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13, 13] ``` --- # Ending I hope you enjoy this kata Good luck!
